comments.text:
The story of the image. The story of the lines. There colour. There movement. There form. 
The video suggests that McLaren embodies the shape of movement, and that shape is manifested in the wind around it. The video makes you understand, in layman terms from the beggining. It assumes only the able mind. The light pulses into an epic climax where it 'illuminates' the outline of true McLaren design. Then it fades to its signature red and white, so too is﻿ its capability. Possible with McLaren.

comments.author: FieraDevilWings

comments.text:
According to the reports, it won't have that setup. So this can't actually be considered a McLaren F1 successor - it's going to have two seats (apparently the driver's seat would be put closer to the centre, known as the "Driver Zone") and it's running a V8 twin-turbo, presumably modified from the 12C's own - running over 700 HP, possibly 800. As well as a KERS system with 200 HP, for a possible total of 1000 HP under the﻿ bonnet.
All in all, the next F1 won't come for a while...
comments.author: FieraDevilWings

comments.text:
Don't know whether to thumb down or to point out that Ferrari aren't the sole dominatrix of the supercar segment. Heck, the power's approaching hypercar status for two of the competitors - McLaren P12 Project, Ferrari F70. Porsche 918 Spyder, not so much.

A sole company can't dominate entirely - otherwise there's no﻿ incentive to imrpove, as you have no benchmark to beat of your opponent's own.
comments.author: FieraDevilWings

Just to clarify, what of Pagani's machines did that time on the Ring, and if it was the Zonda R (which isn't street legal) which is their fastest street legal time?

And I also ask the same question that James May﻿ asks: Why is it so important to have Ring times that beat the rest? It sacrifices a lot just to be "recognised".

comments.text:
Manual's not likely, I can tell you that much. If they were to make a true F1 successor, it's actually pretty﻿ hard to see whether they would develop a new V12 or use the latest in BMW's ///M V12 ones like the old F1 did at the time. It could go either way (if it does happen) considering they have a successful engine, whilst Pagani's Zondas pretty much did the same thing as McLaren by using an AMG V12.
3 seater position...that one's also difficult to see if it would ever be implemented again.

comments.text:
Neither ;) It's all in camera.

It was a 3D setup, rendered in 650 slices over 1000 frames (so 650,000 frames) run through a TV,﻿ and shot on a long exposure. Very complex motion control setup, with fantastically organic looking results.,

comments.text: Wow,﻿ man. It sounds like you're missing the whole point here. If Ferrari gave a rat's ass about who beat them around the track more than they care about the overall feeling induced by their cars, they would be the first to twin turbo everything they sell and equip them with electronics that prohibit the rear end of the car from getting out around turns, like McLaren. The 12C and the 458 are completely different machines. Neither one is ultimately "better" under the premise of it being faster.
